reviewText:
This game is too cheaply made to really be worth your time. The story is cookie fodder -- early -- Final Fantasy fare, the chosen hero has to save the world yadda yadda yadda.
The only unique feature which tries to set it apart from other RPGMaker games is the cheesecake portraits of female characters, which heavily feature in the store front screenshots.

The main problem is easily seen in all the random battles: there is absolutely no art consistency in this game. Backgrounds are pixel paintings, player characters are minute chibi sprites and as for the enemies, they are without exception several times larger than the player sprites and of various differing art styles, ranging from generic slime to highly detailed soldier. Battles use RPGMaker default rules and there isn't even a selection cursor showing just which of the many enemies on screen is 'Soldiers A' and which is 'Soldiers D' -- note the plural.

The game text has multiple grammar and spelling errors, and even complete novice errors such as referring to a DESCENDANT of someone as ANCESTOR.

Other problems include the complete lack of indicators on sprites that are affected by status impairments such as poisoned, while with player characters there is some indicator in the battle screens, there is no such info for enemies. Combine with the lack of identification of individual enemies and you have to remember which enemy has which status...

There is also no health bar for enemies, or even any indication that they may be close to death. Fortunately (?) they are all very easy. Without grinding, I only died once during the entire game, and that was a scripted loss. Even the optional bosses are extremely easy to beat.

On top of all that, the game ends on a clfifhanger with a 'to be continued'.

All in all, if this were a free RPGMaker game I'd be supportive of it as the game creator does have a good idea of what makes a decent oldschool RPG game, but for a commercial release that is sold for money, I expect more. So I just can't honestly recommend it.

reviewText:
A very, very paint-by-the-numbers kind of RPG. There's just so little going on here. This game has a very low price point, which I suppose is the only true saving grace about it, but that's literally it. I suppose I should say that as a first effort, it's THAT bad, but it's pretty forgettable as a whole. Keep in mind it also ends with a bland cliff hanger and a 'to be continued...' screen, but more attention should have been paid into making this one rather than any intent on going to a sequel. There's not much to recommend.

Disappointments about Chosen:
1. Possibly the most generic RPG I've ever played. Forgettable non-personality characters with run of the mill anime names (Edge, Serenity, Akuma). Tired order versus chaos storyline. Even the 'twist' at the end is utterly predictable.

2. Super easy. I never needed to grind. Enemies, including the special bosses and the final villain, all hit like wet socks. Had decent gear by the end, but not anything great, nor did I need anything better. A quiz at the end of the game has no penalties, you just keep answering different things until you get it right. A few pushing boulder puzzles that I could do in my sleep.

3. No character has any personality. They speak a few lines, but they're all honestly interchangable and faceless. Only the main character has anything that can be described as a motivation. Heck, one of the party members even shares the same image as her ruler's full image, except the latter has a dress and a tiara.

4. Lack of a navigation system. There's no map feature and if you miss or forget the quick blurb between story events about what direction to go to, good luck. The overworld has limited defining features at best. They're just empty islands with one, occasionally two enterable places at best. I spent more time wandering around between playing sessions trying to figure out where I was supposed to go than anything else.

5. The whole experience... it's just lazy. Words running off the screen, with frequent grammar mistakes. Incomplete maps, numerous empty traveling screens with no monsters or anything to do on them. Generic bikini clad party members for quick eyecandy sales. If you want some cheesecake, play Huni Pop, because you won't see much of anything beyond the screen shots above. Numerous NPCs in the last town don't speak whatsoever, unlike ones from previous towns. Oh, and the last area? There's no wandering monsters. In fact, you can pay gold to literally buy experience points.

A couple of acceptable points...

1. The aforementioned low price point. Mind you, this was also on sale when it came out...

2. Music is generally good...? Not certain how much is RPG maker (the game makers use a ton of common RPG maker assets) and how much was custom made, if any.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I was given a key for free!!

The Chosen RPG is a casual old-school 16bit era JRPG style made with RPGMaker VX Ace that despite it doesn't bring anything new to the genre and won't probably stand out much from other more impressive RPGMaker games, still manages to  keep the player entertained over the course of it's short length.

The story focuses on Edge, the main protagonist who  becomes the Chosen one to fight evil. While on his quest he teams up with some scantly dressed girls (no, this is not an eroge, or erotic/porn game). Due to it's simplicity the story doesn't drag on nor the dialogues get to long and/or boring, but the way forward is always clear and the player will always know where to go to next and what to do.

Battlesystem too, works very well.  Turnbased battles are fairly easy and don't require you to be on your guard all the time. As the characters level up the will eventually unlock more specials skills and/or spells in tradition RPG manner.

Overall I can recommend The Chosen RPG to  JRPG beginners, casual players and fans of the genre who are looking for a relaxing not too engaging short focused experience. Considering it's price tag and the fact that it is not broken (yes there is a small glitch that lets you fight a boss over and over again, but since this may easily be used for level grinding it isn't really a drawback, nor is it actually game breaking) The Chosen RPG deserves a recommendation. You get what you see advertised in the video and the screenshots!

reviewText:
I was fortunate enough to get to play this game the day before general release date.

As you can tell already from the pictures, you are a (chosen) normal guy thrust into a grand storyline with a party of girls in bikini's, not much to complain about!

Pros:• An interesting storyline with a fairly averaged size open world for a game of this quality (indie RPG maker)
• The ability to have other ways of travelling (such as ships/air ships)
• A few hidden secrets that are not essential to the game, but are an added bonus that can take some hunting
• Intriguing art - although the RPG itself is in the usual RPG maker art, the art of the characters is a nice addition to a standard of game that usually wouldnt bother.
• The ability to sprint, thank god! Moving slowly in games like this can be tedious.
• Easy achievements if you're into that (can get all from <3 hours of play)

Cons:• The speed bubbles can take some time to open/close if you're impatient like me.
• There is a minimal glitch that has a flickering screen if you load with full screen, simply toggle between non-fullscreen and fullscreen to fix instantly.
• Although it does have an open world aspect, the game is still a bit linear in the sense that certain locations can only be entered/opened once achieving something in the storyline.
• The bosses havent been difficult, although I have ventered into areas seemingly too early and died very easily, which is a harsh punishment as my last save was an hour ago.. But if you face bosses // stages when you're meant to, theyre reasonably easy to beat (some you dont even need to heal)

---

The game is what you'd expect overall, if it is something you're looking for, then you'd obviously enjoy it.
Do not expect a massive 40+ RPG because you will not receive it.
If you're looking for a simple RPG that will interest you throughout its short-average lifespan, then this is a good buy for sure.


However, if you're looking to burn a few hours on a decent story that is set up to continue, and support a good game from some indie developers, then give it a go, I know I definitely enjoyed the game and more or less played it through and through :)

reviewText: I'm a fan of RPG games and when I especially played The Chosen RPG for the first time, it really reminded of old - school RPGs. The game itself is really fun and I like how you can travel using a boat to go to different places or environments, whatever you call them. Also there is one thing that I find really weird about this game. Warning: This is a spoiler of the game! Once you go to the Snow Temple to get the God's Wing and defeat the Ice Queen. There is an exploit that you can kill her again. To do this, finish the conversation with all your four teammates, Edge, Trinity, Serena, and Mystic, once they're done talking. Then you'll see the Ice Queen is still there. When you talk to her, she says the same thing that she would say when you battle her. Then here's the weird part you get to battle her again. I've been doing this exploit for like 30 minutes and pretty much overleved my characters. Normally, my characters were lvl 17 when we faced her. The result after the exploit, my characters were lvl 30. So if you're looking into trying out this method, I'd really recommend doing it if you're having trouble killing bosses like Akuma and the dragon boss.

reviewText:
This was a review copy given to me.

Conclusion:
For $2. it's worth checking out. You will like it if you are into the old school RPG's and can handle anime girls with nipples popping out.  Very simple mechanics and often times unforgiving.

Important Stuff:
Can’t remap keyboard, controller is recommended.
Made with RPG Maker
Missing many current features found in RPG’s made in the last 2 decades.
Save Save Save

Good Stuff
Old school feel and charm
Good Story
No tutorial

Bad Stuff
Confusing at times, example the first quest is to go to the graveyard. The graveyard is a tree on the map.
No quest log or helpers
Combat is very standard 90’s JRPG.
Overdone anime girls.
No auto-saves, I lost 5 levels the first time I died because I only saved once way back at the beginning.

Review
Hop in your time machine and come back to 1995 with me. When RPG’s did not have hour long tutorials and there were no guides on the internet on how to play.  This is the time that The Chosen One is living in.  Is that a bad thing? Well it depends on what you like in your RPG. If you enjoy learning a game by playing it and having to read the text to figure out what to do next, then this is for you. It is rough around the edges in many places. I know I am hilarious, that’s a pun since the main characters name is Edge.  Many people who have never played an old school RPG will feel like it’s missing a lot of key features, which by today’s standards is true.  It also has a lot of little quirks that are annoying but not game breaking. However it does possess a certain charm and so far the story is decent (2 hours in).  It does remind me of ChronoTrigger, which is dear to my heart. With that said my mom would of gave me a very stern look of wtf are you playing if she would of walked in while one of the anime girls were on the screen in this one. I wish they would have just left that out its not needed. I will update this review as I get to play more.

You move with the directional keys, access your menu with x, and interact with things via enter. Not entirely sure if this has gamepad support or not.
